reviews.review_text: Hexcells uses similar logical reasoning skills to Minesweeper, but without the timed aspect. Great puzzle game but way too short.

I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoys brain stimulating puzzles, its fun and I love the music.  _______________________________________________________________________ Step 1: Install Step 2: Play Step 3: Finish world 4 and look at the clock Step 4: Run like a madman to where you were supposed to get to an hour ago  10/10 would miss appointments again.

An interesting puzzler that is akin to a mix of Minesweeper and Picross with a very chill ambient soundtrack and a no-rush approach to solving the increasingly complex hex cell maps. Cheap and fun time killer for those stressed days, just don't expect too much content or replay-ability on the long run. 4/5

Great OCD timewaster!  The game is a mix of Minesweeper and Piccross within Hexagonal cells. It has beatufiul minimalistic graphics and it is very well organized within itself, keeping the player aware of new mechanics and making everything simple but escalating from it.  If you like Minesweeper, puzzles, have OCD tendencies, or just want to waste some time having fun while keeping your head occupied, then this game is for you.

I finished the whole thing and all of its thirty-ish levels in one day because it was that fun. I'm exhausted.  Hexcells is a logic puzzle that's similar to other number games like Minesweeper and Picross, as you use processes of elimination and deduction to fill in patterns of tiles. The distinction here is that since the tiles are hexagons, they're not restricted by square grids, and most puzzles look like abstract shapes or very loosely defined objects. Black-background hexes have numbers on them from 0-6, indicating how many of the gold tiles around them can be clicked to turn blue, which counts toward stage completion.  Those hexes are a mixed blessing--finding all of them is the whole point of the game (though you do have to mark every single tile, whether you believe it to be a blue 'hit' or a black 'guide'), but unless you know how many blue tiles are in a given area, these don't often give any information on the tiles around them. The numbers themselves eventually adopt additional characteristics that give you more information on how to complete a stage, but it's well worth remembering that making a decision about one tile necessarily is effectively making a decision about all of the tiles next to it as well. Levels are divided up into groups and sometimes able to be completed out of order, and completing each level perfectly will often mean you unlock the next set even without fully having to finish the previous one.  The game is easy to learn, with simple controls and all of the rules explained as you need them, and there are no hectic time limits to worry about. (I don't know if there's a way to save during levels.) You'll probably build up enough stress just by trying to finish levels without making mistakes, as difficulty ramps up quickly and there's no quick way to restart stages, that I know of, without exiting back out to the level-select menu. This may serve the purpose of discouraging cheating, though. It would be nice to be able to turn the music on and off during a level, but the little 'bloop' sounds the tiles make when clicked go really well with the gentle soundtrack, so much so that you might not notice them at first.  You can make guesses about what tiles are where, but it's much more satisfying to finish a stage or even a small section of one because you understood the rules than because you happened to get lucky. The game doesn't need reflexes, but it expects and encourages patience and discipline (try not to scream if you misclick toward the end of a level you've been chipping away at for half an hour), all for the cost of a small meal.

Hexcells is a minesweeper like games with much improvent. Just started the game and been hooked up for 2 hours and suddenly I have finished the game with 100% achievement. Really simple and entertaining.  I would recommend to buy the whole series. There is trilogy of this game (Hexcells, Hexcells Plus, & Hexcells Infinite).

Hexcells  is a minimalistic logic puzzle very similar to classic Minesweeper. You need to find blue cells and numbers show you how many of them are nearby.   What makes Hexcells better than Minesweeper?    For one, there is no instadeath. If you make a mistake, you just keep going.    Most importantly with a little bit (and sometimes with  a lot ) of thinking you can figure out where each blue cell is located. Unlike minesweeper where sooner or later you come to a point when you have to close your eyes and guess randomly.   Music is very nice and the game itself is relaxing.   The first game is short and puzzles are easy to crack. It took me ~3 hours to perfect all 36 levels. It helps to learn mechanics of the game but it won’t last long. I recommend buying  Hexcells Complete Pack  (Hexcells, Hexcells Infinite, Hexcells Plus) because you will definitely want more.

Completed the game with 100%, Loved it.  Can recommend it to people who like Puzzlegames like Nonograms (Mario's Picross) combined with a bit of Minesweeper and Sudoku.  Pick up the bundle as long as it's in a cheap deal!

A modern classic of a puzzle game let down only by short length, and lack of a level generator or level editor/workshop support. A fantastic advertisement for Hexcells Plus, and Matthew Brown's games in general.  When this started, I was thinking (as apparently everyone else does) 'updated Minesweeper, with better music and graphics.'  As more gameplay mechanics were introduced, I stopped thinking about minesweeper - this is something mch, much more intelligent and much, much more involving. It's still a game where you're deducing the position of tiles that should be left-clicked and ones that should be right-clicked, but the ways you determine which are which change as the game progresses, allowing for some intricate and elegant puzzle solving.  The new gameplay elements represent both a challenge and a tool, meaning the game feels incredibly well-balanced - you're unlikely to ever throw your hands up because something became too complicated. Rules are added as if the entire game were a complete tutorial, to the point that in the later stages, you notice the position of something at a different angle to before, and you instantly understand what this means.  All new rules are introduced with a mini-tutorial puzzle so you get the chance to try them out on the small stage before moving on to a larger-scale puzzle. You can restart and replay levels, which is great if you're like me and have the kind of fingers that left-click when you wanted them to right-click. I think I had one level where I made the same one mistake 5 times, just through being cackhanded... and it's not like I've never played any Portal game, so the blame is squarely at my feet for any frustration I experienced there. That's a nice thing about this puzzle game - it's very friendly, very calming. I complained only at myself (for having stupid fingers, or for making a dumb move), never, ever at the game.  The game looks beautiful - cool colors, minimalist layout - my only gripe is that the menu text looked a bit washed out on my screen - it took a while to be able to see the 'Quit' text - for example - and the music is excellent, accompanied by ambient chimes that play in tune with the music - if you wanted to you could turn the solving of a level into a pretty pleasing musical performance with a little practice.  Achievements are slightly bugged, in that you'll only get them (or at least I only did) the next time you start the game and continue your last save slot. And that's where the game has its biggest letdown - as I understand it, it only has 6 worlds. Not getting the achievements the first time through, made me think that perhaps each world was made up of 6 sets of puzzles, and that the numbers on the homescreen represented the first 3 worlds. Not so. I've unlocked the final world just now, and my game is registering around 2.2 hours played - and that includes leaving the game running for at least half an hour while I did something else.  There's probably 2 hours of gameplay for most people in this, which you may feel is not enough to justify whatever price is being charged. I got this via the Bundlestars Indie Capsule 2, so at most it was around $5 (if I ignored all the other games in that bundle), and I feel that was definitely worth the price.   To sum up - Hexcells is a game that seems at once familiar and modern, is challenging without being frustrating, looks good, sounds good, is good value for money, and is a satisfying gameplay experience that leaves you wanting more of the same.   Get it. It is good.

As many people said: It's pretty much like Minesweeper, but(!) in a new way you wouldn't expect. It tooked the basic concept and evolved it with fresh features and a mdern interface. You never feel like playing a simple clone or an old rusty game. The Levels are preconstructed which makes u avoid the logical dead ends known from Minesweeper. But actually that's a downside too! It took me 1:30h to solve all puzzles in the game and earn every arcivement. For 5€ this would ve been way to less. I can only recommend this game because buying the double package for 2.50€ seems fair to me for this nice little puzzle game.

Hexcells is a puzzle game in which you can use hard logic and intuition to solve the puzzles. If all the numbers put you off, t is less mathematical it appears, focusing more on deciphering patterns. The relaxing sounds are a nice contrast to how hard your brain will work. I thoroughly enjoyed all three and highly recommend them.

This is a lovely logic game that I would describe as a mix between Minesweeper and Picross, but, thankfully, with none of the 'guessing' that's needed in the former. It's presented very nicely with spare but pretty visuals, an ambient soundtrack, and little touches like your actions creating different sounds (so if you solve the puzzle quickly enough, it sounds like you make little songs). It's not very long or very hard (it took me ~100 minutes to finish with 99% hexes--my only mistakes being when I accidently clicked the wrong button), but it's sweet while it lasts :)
Simple. Relaxing. Achievements are attainable. A great puzzle game to pass the time. For $2.99 its well worth the purchase.  I recommend this game.  8.5/10

What a ridiculously good concept for a puzzle game. Seriously.  This blends the mechanics of minesweeper and nonograms (picross) into one great idea.  The fans of these types of games know who they are already; we're a small crowd. If you love the logic based solutions of minesweeper and picross you will love this. The presentation is crisp and clean and works perfectly fine. That's really all the review you need.  This feels like just the tip of the iceberg of Hexcells. It lasts just long enough to get you used to the mechanics of the puzzles and I can't wait to dig into more advanced stuff with Hexcells Plus and Infinite.  Highly recommended (for the puzzle fans out there). And hats off to the creator, Matthew Brown. What a great idea.

I played through this whole thing in one sitting today (around 3 hours). I always thought Minesweeper was a better game than it was given credit for, and Hexcells improves on Minesweeper in pretty much every way. There is no guessing in Hexcells, everything is completely 100% solvable. There are also some interesting new mechanics at play, like seeing the 'mine' count for certain rows or columns, or getting information beyond just a number, like whether all the adjacent mines are touching each other or not. I was VERY pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed this, and I'm looking forward to trying out the other Hexcells games soon.  Side note-- the function of the left and right click are swapped from how they are in Minesweeper. If you have played a decent amount of Minesweeper, do yourself a huge favor and swap the Hexcells controls before you start playing. I didn't, and it screwed with me more than I'd care to admit.

Hexcells is a singleplayer puzzle game, in the vein of Minesweeper, except using a hexagonal grid. Tiles will contian numbers, which indicates the number of tiles which they border which need to be flagged - you mark those tiles, and logically work to clear the board. In later levels, there are other rules which apply (totals for columns, requiring the markers to be contiguous or explicitly non-contiguous, etc).  Hexcells is a rather easy game - I was able to complete it in roughly an hour and a half without difficulty. Hexcells Plus, another game by the same developer, takes what was started in this game and makes it into a much harder, more complete experience. If you're looking for a nice, simple puzzler that's similar to Minesweeper? Sure, this game will scratch that itch. It's not difficult, though. If you're looking for more of a challenge? Feel free to take a pass and go straight for Hexcells Plus.

9/10   - Puzzles   Achievements   - Easy to get 100% completion (around 3 hours)  This is a fun, casual, and short strategy game. It is essentially an updated minesweeper. There is no story. It is just strategic puzzles.  Buy it on sale! It only took around 3 hours for me to beat it and get 100% achievements--as a note for achievers: if you don't get a perfect score the first time (0 mistakes), just repeat the level until you do. This way it isn't confusing later going back to try for the 'perfectionist' achievement because the game doesn't keep track of what levels have mistakes or not!  It also gets frustrating a few times when you have to make guesses over what few left over hexagons to click (luckily, this doesn't happen often) which makes the game a memory game as well if you want to get a perfect score. You can also just screen shot it for quick reference. :]  Updated for formatting.

I really don't understand the appeal.   In this game, like minesweeper, you have to find the 'mines' with the number of adjacent mines of one tile. The difference are that few levels of Hexcell aren't randomly generated and more complex mechanics are introduced as you go on.   The first problem I have with this game is that it does not let you fail. Rather than failing a level for hitting a 'mine', it only count your mistake. It sound like a good thing, but it simply inadvertently spoils the game. I admit that I don't know what could be done to fix this, but nevertheless its the equivalent to trying to solve a math problem with the answer in front of you. You might do your best not to look, you still end up figuring something that you wouldn't have normally.  The second problem is related to the few inconsistencies of the game. It's a minor issue, but sometimes, it seems that the game take liberties with its own rules (or simply doesn't set them). For example;  Two mines in a row of four tiles are said to be next to each other? Turn out that 'next to each other' still count when the row is separated by a huge white space.   symbols like '--' indicate that mines aren't next to each other? It only mean that at least one mine is not connected to the others.  etc.  Like a said, this is a minor issue, but combined with a very short unpunishing game, it doesn't leave you anything worthwhile. I can't recommend this game when other interesting puzzle games are available for the same price.

It's a rather short game, but the puzzles are interesting and the game keeps bulding upon it's mechanics so it's varied despite not having many levels.  Recommended.

I bought this because I loved Everyday Genius: Square Logic, and it looked similar. The game is beautiful and music is relaxing and great to listen too. My biggest gripe is how short the game is. I bought this and in less than 2 hours I was complete and had perfect on every level. It's a fun little game but it should be a 99 cent app, not a full fledged game. Perhaps some more complex levels or new ways of doing things could help, but as is, I'd rate this a 5/10.

It IS an abstract puzzle, like minesweeper or sudoku or something like that, and it has a nice atmospheric sound and visuals to go along with it, but that's all it really is, honestly. It feels really insubstantial. Simply adding more levels isn't what I want, either. Nor is adding more mechanics. I just think it's hard to make an abstract puzzle game feel as fun as some of the other games out there. It took me 2-3 hours to 100% and I didn't really end it feeling like I was glad I played it.   Plus, the music loop starts to get annoying after awhile. It's too short, plays too often, and isn't mixed in with other tracks.   And the core gameplay loop is pretty much just - reveal the obvious stuff, then hunt around for the next thing you can reveal. That's not that fun to me compared to what you do in other games. It's not the lack of action or anything - I'm fine with slow-paced, turn-based, or other puzzle games. It's just the lack of problem solving - this game is all deduction and very little intuition. I like working with and experimenting with a hard problem and going over it in my head and trying different avenues of solutions and trying to come up with observations and rules and constraints that I can use to simplify the problem. You can find that core gameplay loop in lots of excellent puzzle games, but you won't find it here.  If you like minesweeper or sudoku you should definitely give this a try. Otherwise, even if you're a huge fan of puzzle games like me, I'd probably avoid this. You're not going to find that problem-solving engagement and stimulation here, unlike what you'd find in lots of other puzzle games. There's no experimenting, discovery, or anything like that. It's just 'oh here's the next spot for which I can prove its contents' and 'hmm, where's the next one?'.  As a counterexample, an abstract puzzle game I DID enjoy was Splice (you might argue that it's not TRULY abstract since it uses a sort of biological metaphor, but I think of it as one). That game has plenty of that 'problem solving high' you get as you experiment and observe and work through a complex problem.

This game plays very much like Minesweeper, as in every hexagon tells you how many of surrounding tiles you have to 'find'. There is a fixed number of increasingly difficult puzzles but once you got the hang of it, net one is really challanging. A big downside is the lack of a random level generator, which is the reason I cannot give this game a full recommendation -- even though I find it generally more enjoyable than the Windows counterpart (and its Linux clones.)

Minesweeper players will be pleased to hear that all of the puzzles can be solved without any guesswork, but may be annoyed that 'mark' and 'uncover' are on the opposite mouse buttons to what players are used to (and can't be changed). The game takes a tad too long to get challenging, and is over a little too soon when it does, but I don't feel short-changed from the 67 pence sale price. I'll be looking to get the sequels on sale at some point in the future.

One mistake is forgivable when attempting to max score a level, but 2 mistakes starts taking points away giving just enough leeway to take an educated guess when faced with difficult decisions.
Like a much better version of minesweeper: it provides *just* enough information to solve a level.

Great number logic puzzle. At its core, it's a hex-grid Minesweeper, but with more varied ways of giving you clues. The initial release Hexcells' puzzles are much too easy, but the subsequent releases Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite have much more suitably challenging puzzles. Highly recommended for those who enjoy good number logic puzzles.

It's elegant. It's fun to play. I love the ambient atmosphere with which the game pulls you in and makes you focus.  But then there's the disappointing realization that after 3 hours it's all over. Every achievement conquered. Every puzzle finished. 100% score. That was a serious downer that makes me doubt whether to give thumbs up or down.  In the end the low price of 3 euros makes it a thumb up.

Very nice mine sweeper-like game. But it's too short and easy. If you know these puzzles, you'll appreciate the ingenuity put in Hexcells.

This is a relaxing puzzle game. The music is soothing. I've beaten the whole game several times, but I enjoy starting over and playing again. It's kind of like Minesweeper, but it has added elements that make it way better.  One thing I appreciate is that there is no guesswork or random clicking needed. You should be able to solve each puzzle with the clues provided.
Great puzzle game, tons of fun, for a ridiculous price

A decent little logic puzzler, well worth the usual sale price under a dollar.  Special note: I almost didn't get this, because the description makes it sound like Minesweeper on a hexagonal grid. Relaxing, 'must finish' and 'just another one to go' puzzler.
A simply great puzzle game for the logically minded. Well made with a good increase in difficulty with each stage. Loved it.

Very fun to play. Delightful sounds. It's similar to minesweeper, but not exactly the same. Better. Very recommended to kill time. The only con is that the game is short, but it's worth the price. 10/10.

Dear Developer, first off f*** you for designing this really elegant iteration of Minesweeper. I had ideas for years on how to improve Minesweeper to make it less punishing and more fun for casual players. You managed to improve on every aspect of this really frustrating classic. Minesweeper and sudoku and any other ingenius logic deduction puzzler just came together and had glorious sex. Logic Puzzles.   Pros The idea is fantastic. The game is easy to learn, In fact, it's a LOT like minesweeper without actually being minesweeper. It's much better in my opinion. The graphics are minimalist, which emphasize the clean logic of the game. The music is calm and relaxing.  Cons It's short. I finished all the puzzles in 2.5 hours. The logic only goes so far. For a casual gamer this is probably a plus. You don't have to derive clues from more than 2 orders. But a few of the later puzzles will make you do a lot of 2nd order deductions. But just when it was getting really, really good..it ended *pouty face* Not much for replay value. You can play the puzzles again. But you should probably let the game accumulate some dust and come back to it in a year, then it will probably be fun all over again.  Summary It's fun. I really like it, but it's just so short!
I got this and the Plus version, can't wait to try it. This is just like Minesweeper and alot of fun. I would recomend this to anyone who likes puzzles or Minesweeper.

Neat puzzle game like minesweeper. Fun game if you like puzzle games, though it suffers from a few UI issues like having to exit a puzzle compeltely to restart it. Other than that really well done.

I love the multidirectionality of Hexcells: solving a single cell can affect three lines of cells, as well as the set of surrounding cells. At first, it felt much like a hexagonal version of Minesweeper. When the lines were added, I was reminded of nonograms / paint-by-numbers puzzles. Then, as the puzzles continued, my mind became so occupied with the intersecting logic that I stopped trying to compare it to other games at all.   It may be worth skipping this and going directly to Hexcells Plus. First, if you get easily addicted to logic puzzles, Hexcells Plus will keep you thinking for much, much longer. Second, Hexcells Plus' difficulty ramps up slowly and consistently, never adding more than a few techniques at a time. The puzzle difficulty from the original Hexcells increases smoothly at first, but jumps dramatically in the second half. It's a great challenge, but also changes the rhythm of play.
Minesweeper meets Picross. 2 solid hours of gameplay.

As an avid fan of both, Picross and Minesweeper, this game was like heaven. It's a bit short and only the last few levels are at all challenging, but it is lots of fun and definitely worth $3 and a couple of hours.

It looks a little bit like Hexic, plays a little bit like minesweeper and it's pretty much impossible to put down. Worth every penny for the few hours you'll get out of it.

It progresses in difficulty and forces you to use logic and deducing. I really enjoyed it because it was so relaxed and calming. I would recommend this for puzzle and number enthusiasts and casual gamers alike.

Note: This review is for both Hexcells, Hexcells Plus and Hexcells Infinite, because they're basically a single game divided in three parts.  The Hexcell games are a series of brilliant crafted puzzles that at first glance may seem like a six-sided minesweeper, but the logic used to solve them is closer to sudoku. As you progress through the levels, you are also introduced to some new mechanics accompained by a tutorial level to make sure that you understand them. Because the puzzles are carefully and wonderfully designed, you never have to guess your next move, but finding it gets hard in the later puzzles. The interface is clean and the sound effects are cool. Hexcells is easy, Hexcells Plus gets harder in the second half and Hexcells Infinite steps back a little at the beginning, but in the end offers the most challenging puzzles. It also comes with a seed-based puzzle generator, adding 999,999,999 additional puzzles (even if they aren't hand crafted, they're still good). My recommendation is that you get and play all three games in order, but if you can only pick one, pick Hexcells Infinite, it's main levels difficulty is nicely spread not to mention the puzzle generator.

Matthew Brown's small bundle of puzzles are all satisfying to solve, a feeling made even more apparent when Brown delivers on his promise that each puzzle can be solved without taking any guesses.  Hexcells is a wonderful introduction to the trilogy, and I highly recommend that anyone with even a vague fascination with puzzles take a shot at it - it's $2.99 god damn it, and well worth it.  If you've got the $8.99, you might as well buy the whole Hexcells Trilogy instead - I guarantee that stopping at Hexcells won't be enough.

That being said, it serves very well as an introduction to the series. I got this one on sale and now I'll probably buy the other ones too. All in all, it's very nice to play. Very simple concept, comfortable difficulty curve, well-built levels. The music is also quite good, with your moves participating in the sonic environment.  Again, very much recommended.

A nice relaxing puzzle. Very reminiscent of minesweeper, and additional elements added later on also reminded me of Picross. I completed the game on a lazy Saturday and it gave me enough challenge that it didn't feel like a breeze. Additionally, it never vexed me by being too difficult or requiring me to know the intricacies of how everything worked (those hidden rules you find after doing a puzzle for a long time).   If there's one thing to note, it's that the 'Perfectionist' achievement does NOT require you to get 0 mistakes on all levels, just to get all of those hexagonal 'points'. This is good, because there's several levels where I got 1 honest mistake and it didn't deduct anything.  The game also punishes random 'spam n' solve' play by making it impossible to unlock later levels without X number of aforementioned hexagonal points. Why you would do that anyway is beyond me.  My only critique of the game is a lack of puzzles with all the elements added. Initially, the game starts off by showing you the base points, then shows you that lines and columns can have numbers too, and then shows you how to toggle everything; and suddenly, you're two-thirds of the way through the puzzles. Just a minor gripe, but getting Hexcells Plus & Infinite solves that problem nicely.

Edit: I came back to this game again later, and had a much better time with it. I think part of my problem is that I've played way too much minesweeper, which is timed. This isn't a puzzle game to rush, so much. Once I slowed down and paid attention, it was pretty fun.  It looks pretty and sounds pretty, but the actual gameplay is frustrating. I kept running into situations where the puzzle just wasn't giving me enough information to continue without guessing--which is penalized.
